Content:
Topic: Intro to Dramatic Literature: The Nature of The P
ART-SHU 200 | 2 units | Class#: 20331 | Session: SH 09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 001
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Grp Instr in the Perform Arts
09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 Fri 1.00 PM - 3.30 PM with Mirrione, James
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. A creative exploration of four plays that illustrate of the arc of dramatic literature throughout history and the synergy of dramaturgical components even as they span the centuries. By means of reading, discussing and exploring the various production elements of each of these plays, students will attain an awareness and working knowledge as to what defines a play as an engaging sensory experience; one that also serves as a catalyst for exploring their timelessness and application to current trends and controversies. Culminating projects include an experiential exercise/presentation based on the work studied and individual production portfolio by advisement.

Topic: Theory and Practice
ART-SHU 200 | 2 units | Class#: 20332 | Session: SH 09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 002
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Grp Instr in the Perform Arts
09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 Fri 4.30 PM - 7.00 PM with Mirrione, James
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. This course is focused on the theoretical and practical techniques necessary for the actor to live truthfully within the imaginary circumstances of a character. Students participate in group and individual activities centered on self-observation, applying discoveries to improvisations, monologues, and scene work. At the onset of the class, one filmic version of the chosen play is viewed, (and if possible, attendance at a live performance of the same text), which will serve as the touchstone for class members to explore the various tenets and themes of the play, especially as to how they inform acting choices. In the first part of the semester students will concentrate on a series of lessons designed to facilitate exploration of a character's physical, intellectual and social truth. In the second half of the semester students will present monologues of their own choice (subject to approval by instructor) and scenes by applying the lessons and techniques learned. Reading and writing assignments are due as outlined in the course schedule. Class participants should wear suitable clothing for movement and rehearsal.

Topic: Nature of Code
INTM-SHU 230 | 4 units | Class#: 20483 | Session: SH 09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 001
Class Status: Wait List (2) | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Lecture
09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 Tue,Thu 1.45 PM - 3.30 PM with Moon, Jung Hyun
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. Course Description: Can we capture the unpredictable evolutionary and emergent properties of nature in software? Can understanding the mathematical principles behind our physical world world help us to create digital worlds? This class focuses on the programming strategies and techniques behind computer simulations of natural systems. We explore topics ranging from basic mathematics and physics concepts to more advanced simulations of complex systems. Subjects covered include physics simulation, trigonometry, fractals, cellular automata, self-organization, and genetic algorithms. Examples are demonstrated in native JavaScript using p5.js. Much of the class time will be dedicated to in-class exercises and self-study as the course is available online through a video series and textbook. Category: Computation & Data Prerequisite: Interaction Lab or Communications Lab (Priority for IMA majors; others can register on Monday, May 1)

Topic: Generative Language
INTM-SHU 230 | 4 units | Class#: 20486 | Session: SH 09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 002
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Lecture
09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 Mon,Wed 9.45 AM - 11.30 AM with Vasudevan, Roopa
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. Course Description: This class examines the use of text as source material for generative art. The semester will begin with cutting up and remixing text utilizing basic find, replace, and randomization, and will then move on to topics such as regular expressions, Markov generators, Internet bots, natural language processing, and sentiment analysis. We will also look at using and analyzing data from popular social media APIs, as well as scraping and cleaning raw HTML, in order to generate new content. Students will create 3 text-based projects over the course of the semester, in addition to smaller weekly homework assignments, reading, and class discussion. The course will be taught in the Python programming language. Category: Computation & Data Prerequisite: Communications Lab or Interaction Lab

Topic: Toy Design and Prototyping
INTM-SHU 236 | 4 units | Class#: 20462 | Session: SH 09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 001
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Lecture
09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 Tue,Thu 4.45 PM - 6.30 PM with Godoy, Marcela
Notes: The emphasis of this class is on designing toys for play and entertainment, however toys are not only for kids. Toys are part of our culture, and an important medium to develop essential skills like creativity, problem-solving and socialization. They can also be a great contribution in education, medicine, and business and can improve the quality of life for children and adults alike. Students will be introduced to the essential concepts in designing toys and they will create their own by utilizing hand-making craft skills and new technologies. This course will equip students with a basic knowledge about various design topics, including: brainstorming; sketching; graphic design; concept development; mechanisms; 3D modeling; rendering and rapid prototyping. This is a hands on class, and students are required to bring their imagination in addition to a willingness to experiment and explore creative solutions for class assignments. Category: Art & Design Corequisite: Interaction Lab Priority for IMA majors; others can register on Monday, May 1

Topic: Musical Expression (NIME)
INTM-SHU 245 | 2 units | Class#: 20384 | Session: S72 10/30/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 001
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Lecture
10/30/2017 - 12/15/2017 Thu 6.00 PM - 9.00 PM with Wiriadjaja, Antonius
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. Course Description: This course will focus on designing, creating and performing with musical instruments that utilize recent discoveries in interactive media in order to explore the limits of human expression. Over the semester, students are asked to research examples of contemporary work by creators of musical interfaces and discuss a wide range of issues facing technology in the performing arts. Readings and case studies will provide background for class discussions on the theory and practice of designing gestural controllers for musical performance. Students will invent and prototype a complete system encompassing musical control, mapping input to sound, and the creation of sound itself. Interaction Lab is a prerequisite, but prior performing experience is not required. The performance discipline, being an inherently collaborative arena, places heavy emphasis on teamwork. An open mind to work with other artists, technologists and creative leaders is a must. The class will culminate in a performance where students will play their instruments live. New Category: Experimental Interfaces & Physical Computing Old Categories: Skill Development Priority for IMA majors; others can register on Monday, May 1

Topic: Animatronics
INTM-SHU 245 | 2 units | Class#: 20389 | Session: S72 10/30/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 002
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Lecture
10/30/2017 - 12/15/2017 Tue,Thu 9.45 AM - 11.30 AM with Cossovich, Rodolfo
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. Course Description: Animatronics is a multi-disciplinary field which integrates anatomy, mechatronics and puppetry resulting in lifelike animation. In this course we will explore what factors bring devices to emulate a human or an animal. Going through a series of assignments we will bring lifelike characteristics to otherwise unanimated objects. Using open source software we will digitally create characters. Tapping into common prototyping techniques we will create advanced movements in mechanisms that will be dressed up and act as if they were alive. This will not be a tech intensive course but there is a pre-requisite of Interaction Lab because wiring, programming and laser cutting are needed. We will learn how to create sequences of actions and then how to control them remotely. Each of the participants is expected by the end of the course to be able to develop their own animatronic figure and make it behave in a realistic way. New Category: Experimental Interfaces & Physical Computing Old Categories: Interactive Art & Entertainment and Skill Development Corequisite: Interaction Lab Priority for IMA majors; others can register on Monday, May 1

Topic: Introduction to Assistive Technology
INTM-SHU 245 | 2 units | Class#: 20390 | Session: S71 09/04/2017 - 10/27/2017 | Section: 003
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Lecture
09/04/2017 - 10/27/2017 Thu 6.00 PM - 9.00 PM with Petit, Marianne
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. Course Description: Assistive technology is a term that includes a wide variety of technologies for people with disabilities. This two-point survey course is designed to provide students with an overview of the field of assistive technology. Field trips, readings, and guest speakers will provide students with an understanding of current research and development as well as processes used in determining appropriate technologies. Weekly assignments and a final research project. Category: Physical Computing & Experimental Interfaces Prerequisite OR Corequisite: Interaction Lab Priority for IMA majors; others can register on Monday, May 1

Topic: Aesthetics and Literature
HUMN-SHU 230 | 4 units | Class#: 19235 | Session: SH 09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 001
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Seminar
09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 Mon,Wed 11.15 AM - 12.30 PM with Kendrick, Anna
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. Satisfies Humanities Topic Course Description: Literature turns words into images, and images into words. Where do the sensory boundaries between literary and artistic media lie? We will read key texts on visual thinking and aesthetic experience across national traditions, from Greek philosophy to Chinese art, African modernism to American postmodernism. Combining close readings of novels, poetry, photography, and cinema with museum and exhibition visits, students consider the relationship between image and text, author and reader, perception and memory. Authors read include Sei Shonagan, Walter Benjamin, Virginia Woolf, Susan Sontag, Antoni Tàpies, Gao Xingjian, Teju Cole and others.

Class Status: Wait List (2) | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Grp Instr in the Perform Arts
09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 Wed 6.00 PM - 7.30 PM with Wang, Jie
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. Centered around attending a variety of musical performances in Shanghai, in class work will consist of lectures, readings, listening and discussions in advance of the event as well as further discussion and reflection afterwards. Students will work on refining critical listening skills and a greater knowledge of music and music as an integral part of society and in particular, Shanghai’s past and present artistic community. Genres to be chosen from: jazz, classical, indigenous, fusion, theatre music and contemporary pop/rock. This course satisfies 2 credits of the Chinese Arts Core Curriculum.

Topic: Composition and Interpretation
MUS-SHU 200 | 2 units | Class#: 20555 | Session: SH 09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 | Section: 002
Class Status: Open | Grading: Ugrd Shanghai Graded | Instruction Mode: In-Person
Course Location: Shanghai | Component: Grp Instr in the Perform Arts
09/04/2017 - 12/15/2017 Thu 2.00 PM - 3.30 PM
Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. An introductory class in music taught through the study of musical interpretation and composition. With an emphasis on the modern techniques and tools of music composition/production, the aim of this course is to get a simple yet strong compositional tool set in addition to a fundamental knowledge of music and its application as a communicative language. Musical concepts and compositional objectives will be introduced by means listening, sampling and combining different virtual instruments. For the final assignment, each student will compose a short musical piece/song. No need to know how to read music. Students must bring a Mac computer with the following free applications: Garageband Native Instruments Kontakt Player and its virtual instruments library.

Notes: Course Repeatable for Credit. Enrollment with permission of course instructor - see below. This class will study, rehearse and present Noel Coward’s PRIVATE LIVES in 2-3 different venues in Shanghai toward the end of the Fall semester. Students will study the work, the author and its connections to 1930s Shanghai. Each student will have a specific task be it as an actor, singer or part of the production team in fully realizing this piece. *Some additional rehearsal at mutually convenient times may be required as we get closer to the initial performance date. Those interested in participating should contact the instructor below: 7 cast members 5 production and stage crew Students interested in the above should contact Prof. Mirrione 3 singers Students interested should contact Prof. Heldman
